elements.content: During the formation of magnesium-organic frameworks, the coordination sphere of magnesium tends to be partially occupied by O-containing solvent molecules such as amides, which will dramatically decrease the symmetry of Mg-organic frameworks and thus lead to low stability. It is noted that up to now, most reported Mg-metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) (>80%) crystallize in the space groups whose symmetry is lower than that of a tetragonal system. In this work, we demonstrate that acetate (Ac) may act as modulator to eliminate the influence of amide solvent and improve the symmetry of Mg-organic frameworks. Two novel Mg-MOFs, namely, {[(CH3)­NH3]4[Mg3(BTB)8/3(Ac)2(H2O)]} n (SNNU-35, H3BTB = 4′,4′′,4′′′-benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoic acid) and {[(CH3)2NH2]­[Mg2(FDA)2(Ac)]} n (SNNU-36, H2FDA = 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid) were successfully designed, which crystallize in rhombohedral R-3 and tetragonal I4/mmm space groups, respectively. Four independent BTB ligands link three unique Mg cations and generate superlarge [Mg21BTB17] nanocages, which interlock each other by strong π···π stacking to give a two-fold interpenetrating architecture of SNNU-35. On the other hand, carboxylate and acetate groups chelate Mg atoms to form one-dimensional chains, which are extended by FDA to produce the rod-packing framework of SNNU-36. Two microporous Mg-MOFs both exhibit notable CO2 and H2 uptakes. H3BTB and H2FDA ligands both have emission features, and Mg ions usually can enhance the fluorescent intensity, which lead to a strong solid-state luminescence emission property of SNNU-35 and -36. Importantly, two Mg-MOFs both show fast and quantative sensing performance for nitrocompounds. Among three selected models of substrate, SNNU-35 and -36 can eliminate the interference of nitromethane (NM) and exhibit high sensitivity to nitrobenzene (NB) and o-nitrotoluene (2-NT) with large k sv values (>105 M–1). Especially, the fluorescence quenching efficiency of NB (5000 ppm) and 2-NT (8000 ppm) can reach 96.3% and 89.5% and 85.0% and 83.7% for SNNU-35 and -36, respectively. This work offers not only an effective route to improve the symmetry of magnesium-organic frameworks but also two potential fluorescence sensors for nitroaromatic compounds.

elements.content: Two high-symmetrical porous luminescent magnesium-organic frameworks have been designed by acetate as modulator, which exhibit sensitive, fast, quantative and selective fluorescent detection for nitroaromatics.
elements.clean_text: Two high-symmetrical porous luminescent magnesium-organic frameworks have been designed by acetate as modulator, which exhibit sensitive, fast, quantative and selective fluorescent detection for nitroaromatics.

elements.content: In the past few decades, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been rapidly developed. As a kind of porous material, MOFs feature big specific surface area and high porosity, diversity in composition and structure, and display a variety of applications including guest–host interaction, magnetic, gas storage, clean energy, sensing, etc. In particular, fluorescent MOFs have attracted wide attention because of their advantages in sensing applications, including the detection of heavy metal ions, anions, small molecules, and so on. Usually, the functional organic ligands in MOFs consist of π-electron-rich aromatic moieties that can improve fluorescence lifetime, intensity, and quantum efficiencies.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past few decades, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been rapidly developed. As a kind of porous material, MOFs feature big specific surface area and high porosity, diversity in composition and structure, and display a variety of applications including guest-host interaction, magnetic, gas storage, clean energy, sensing, etc. In particular, fluorescent MOFs have attracted wide attention because of their advantages in sensing applications, including the detection of heavy metal ions, anions, small molecules, and so on. Usually, the functional organic ligands in MOFs consist of π-electron-rich aromatic moieties that can improve fluorescence lifetime, intensity, and quantum efficiencies.

elements.content: The fluorescent sensing performance of magnesium-organic frameworks, also called Mg-MOFs, have displayed several advantages as the existence of Mg centers usually can enhance the emission intensity of organic ligands. However, the coordination sphere of magnesium tends to be partially occupied by O-containing solvent molecules such as amides, which will dramatically decrease the symmetry, stability, and even the photoluminescence property of Mg-MOFs. Thus, the elimination of coordinated amide solvents and design of high-symmetrical magnesium-organic frameworks is important for the development of new Mg-MOF fluorescent sensors.
elements.clean_text: The fluorescent sensing performance of magnesium-organic frameworks, also called Mg-MOFs, have displayed several advantages as the existence of Mg centers usually can enhance the emission intensity of organic ligands. However, the coordination sphere of magnesium tends to be partially occupied by O-containing solvent molecules such as amides, which will dramatically decrease the symmetry, stability, and even the photoluminescence property of Mg-MOFs. Thus, the elimination of coordinated amide solvents and design of high-symmetrical magnesium-organic frameworks is important for the development of new Mg-MOF fluorescent sensors.

elements.content: On the other hand, nitroaromatic compounds with the characteristics of combustible, toxic, and explosive are not only environmental pollutants but also explosives endangering the social stability. Rapid and sensitive detection of nitroaromatic compounds is of prime importance. It is noted that the −NO2 of nitroaromatic compounds is an electron-deficient group, while MOFs generally have electron-rich skeletons. Obviously, the combining interaction between nitroaromatics and MOFs can cause the fluorescence attenuation and even achieve the quenching effect. Especially, most Mg-polycarboxylate MOFs are of anionic frameworks, which should have strong interactions with nitrocompounds. Therefore, luminescent Mg-MOFs are excellent chemical sensors in theory to detect trace nitroaromatic compounds.

Rapid and sensitive detection of nitroaromatic compounds is of prime importance. It is noted that the -NO2 of nitroaromatic compounds is an electron-deficient group, while MOFs generally have electron-rich skeletons. Obviously, the combining interaction between nitroaromatics and MOFs can cause the fluorescence attenuation and even achieve the quenching effect. Especially, most Mg-polycarboxylate MOFs are of anionic frameworks, which should have strong interactions with nitrocompounds. Therefore, luminescent Mg-MOFs are excellent chemical sensors in theory to detect trace nitroaromatic compounds.

elements.content: Recently, we have systematically explored the extra-high CO2 uptake performance of Mg-MOFs. During this process, we showed that the additive 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-pentanedione (HFP) can successfully generate rare [Mg3(μ3–OH)­(COO)6] trimeric building blocks and lead to a series of high-symmetrical Mg-MOFs. Herein, we further demonstrate that auxiliary acetate anions may act as modulator to eliminate the coordination of amide and thus lead to high symmetrical Mg-MOFs. Two fluorescent anionic Mg-MOFs, {[(CH3)­NH3]4[Mg3(BTB)8/3(Ac)2(H2O)]} n (SNNU-35, SNNU = Shaanxi Normal University) and {[(CH3)2NH2]­[Mg2(Ac)­(FDA)2]} n (SNNU-36) have been successfully designed by the self-assembly of magnisium cations with two aromatic poly­(carboxylic acid) ligands with emission features (BTB and FDA) and auxiliary acetate anions (Ac). Impressively, π···π stacking induced two-fold interpenetrating architectures of SNNU-35 and rod-packing framework of SNNU-36 both exhibit sensitive, fast, quantative, and selective fluorescent detection for nitroaromatics.

Impressively, π⋅⋅⋅π stacking induced two-fold interpenetrating architectures of SNNU-35 and rod-packing framework of SNNU-36 both exhibit sensitive, fast, quantative, and selective fluorescent detection for nitroaromatics.

elements.content: All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Thermogravimetric analyses were conducted on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C per min in air atmosphere. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies were carried out with a Japan Rigaku D/Max2550VB+/PC diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). C, H, and N elemental analyses (EA) were performed using an Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. FluoroMax-4 spectrofluorometer was used to record the solid-state photoluminescence spectra and luminescent sensing results. The gas sorption isotherms were obtained from the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88 surface area analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods and Materials

All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Thermogravimetric analyses were conducted on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C per min in air atmosphere. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies were carried out with a Japan Rigaku D/Max2550VB+/PC diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). C, H, and N elemental analyses (EA) were performed using an Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. FluoroMax-4 spectrofluorometer was used to record the solid-state photoluminescence spectra and luminescent sensing results. The gas sorption isotherms were obtained from the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88 surface area analyzer.

Colorless transparent bulk crystals were obtained. Yield: 46% relatively to Mg. EA results for desolvent SNNU-35 sample: Calcd (Mg3C80N4H72O21), C, 64.1; H, 4.8; N, 3.7%. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis was performed on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD area diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), operating in the ω and φ scan mode. The SADABS program was used for absorption correction. The single-crystal structures of SNNU-35 and SNNU-36 were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS and refined on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXL program package. The C–H hydrogen atoms were calculated in idealized geometry riding on their parent atoms, and the protic O–H atoms were found and refined. The large volume fractions of solvents and cations in the lattice pores could not be modeled in terms of atomic sites and were treated using the SQUEEZE routine in the PLATON software package. Detailed crystallographic data and the structure refinement parameters are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determinations

Single-crystal X-ray analysis was performed on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD area diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), operating in the ω and φ scan mode. The SADABS program was used for absorption correction. The single-crystal structures of SNNU-35 and SNNU-36 were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS and refined on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXL program package. The C-H hydrogen atoms were calculated in idealized geometry riding on their parent atoms, and the protic O-H atoms were found and refined. The large volume fractions of solvents and cations in the lattice pores could not be modeled in terms of atomic sites and were treated using the SQUEEZE routine in the PLATON software package. Detailed crystallographic data and the structure refinement parameters are summarized in .

The crystal samples of SNNU-35 and -36 (15 mg, respectively) were placed in DMA solution (150 mL) and treated by stirring for 3 h. Before the fluorescence quenching experiments, the DMA solutions of SNNU-35 and -36 sat for 7 days to obtain stable suspensions by filtering. The fluorescence quenching experiments were performed by the incremental addition of DMA solution of various nitro explosives (100–8000 ppm) to a 3 mL DMA suspension of SNNU-35 and -36.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Quenching Experiment

The crystal samples of SNNU-35 and -36 (15 mg, respectively) were placed in DMA solution (150 mL) and treated by stirring for 3 h. Before the fluorescence quenching experiments, the DMA solutions of SNNU-35 and -36 sat for 7 days to obtain stable suspensions by filtering. The fluorescence quenching experiments were performed by the incremental addition of DMA solution of various nitro explosives (100-8000 ppm) to a 3 mL DMA suspension of SNNU-35 and -36.

elements.content: It is noted that during the formation of large single crystals of SNNU-35, 4,4′-bipyridyl is necessary, although it is not observed in the final framework. Moreover, SNNU-35 and -36 both are of high symmetry (R-3 and I4/mmm), which are scarce for Mg-MOFs due to the easy coordination of amide solvent to Mg centers, usually reducing their symmetry. The auxiliary acetate anions in SNNU-35-36 may effectively eliminate the coordination of amide and thus lead to high symmetry. This is similar to our and literature formerly reported distinctive additive 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-pentanedione (HFP), which successfully generates a series of high-symmetrical Mg-MOFs with rare [Mg3(μ3-OH) (COO)6] trimeric building blocks.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

It is noted that during the formation of large single crystals of SNNU-35, 4,4'-bipyridyl is necessary, although it is not observed in the final framework. Moreover, SNNU-35 and -36 both are of high symmetry (R-3 and I4/mmm), which are scarce for Mg-MOFs due to the easy coordination of amide solvent to Mg centers, usually reducing their symmetry. The auxiliary acetate anions in SNNU-35-36 may effectively eliminate the coordination of amide and thus lead to high symmetry. This is similar to our and literature formerly reported distinctive additive 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-pentanedione (HFP), which successfully generates a series of high-symmetrical Mg-MOFs with rare [Mg3(μ3-OH) (COO)6] trimeric building blocks.

elements.content: SNNU-35 crystallizes in the R-3 space group where the basic structure unit contains three crystallographically independent Mg­(II) cations, 8/3 BTB ligands, two Ac anions in situ generated from NMA, and one coordinated H2O molecule (a). Mg1 and Mg2 both are of distorted octahedral geometry surrounded by six oxygen atoms (Mg1: O12, O16, O17, O19, O20, O21; Mg2: O9, O11, O14, O21, O13, O18). Carboxylate O21 acts as a bridge linking Mg1 and Mg2 and thus leads to a binuclear unit reinforced by other two μ2-briding carboxylate groups. The third chelating COO group from BTB, two Ac anions, and one water molecules serving as terminal ligands help to finish the distorted [Mg2(COO)4(Ac)2(H2O)] motif. Thus, each dinuclear cluster is surrounding by four BTB ligands. The Mg3 ion forms a distorted tetrahedral geometry by coordination with four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O5, O7, and O15), and thus each Mg3 also connects four BTB ligands. So the [Mg2] dinuclear and Mg3 mononuclear motifs both can be regarded as 4-connected nodes. All above Mg–O distances are from 1.961(3) Å to 2.236(3) Å, which are within the normal values found for related Mg-MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure of SNNU-35

SNNU-35 crystallizes in the R-3 space group where the basic structure unit contains three crystallographically independent Mg(II) cations, 8/3 BTB ligands, two Ac anions in situ generated from NMA, and one coordinated H2O molecule (a). Mg1 and Mg2 both are of distorted octahedral geometry surrounded by six oxygen atoms (Mg1: O12, O16, O17, O19, O20, O21; Mg2: O9, O11, O14, O21, O13, O18). Carboxylate O21 acts as a bridge linking Mg1 and Mg2 and thus leads to a binuclear unit reinforced by other two μ2-briding carboxylate groups. The third chelating COO group from BTB, two Ac anions, and one water molecules serving as terminal ligands help to finish the distorted [Mg2(COO)4(Ac)2(H2O)] motif. Thus, each dinuclear cluster is surrounding by four BTB ligands. The Mg3 ion forms a distorted tetrahedral geometry by coordination with four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O5, O7, and O15), and thus each Mg3 also connects four BTB ligands. So the [Mg2] dinuclear and Mg3 mononuclear motifs both can be regarded as 4-connected nodes. All above Mg-O distances are from 1.961(3) Å to 2.236(3) Å, which are within the normal values found for related Mg-MOFs.

elements.content: On the other hand, four unique BTB ligands adopt different coordination modes as depicted in Figure S2, which are μ6-kO,O;kO,O;kO,O;kO;kO;kO for BTB-1, μ5-kO;kO;kO;kO;kO for BTB-2, μ3-kO;kO;kO,O for BTB-3, and μ3-kO;kO;kO for BTB-4, respectively. Each BTB-1 connects three [Mg2] units, BTB-2 links two dinuclear motifs and one Mg3 center, BTB-3 connects one dinuclear cluster and two Mg3 ions, and BTB-4 joints three Mg3 monocluster. Overall, all BTB ligands can be regarded as 3-connected nodes.

elements.content: As shown in b, Mg atoms and four BTB ligands interconnect each other to form a superlarge [Mg21BTB17] polyhedral nanocage with a dimension of about 26 Å. Each Mg-BTB nanocage is surrounded by eight same neighbors and thus forms a highly porous 3D architecture of SNNU-35. However, such a Mg-MOF with large metal–organic cages will not be very stable due to the unsteady mono- or dinuclear Mg clusters. So two types of strong π···π stacking interactions (c, the center to center distances are of 3.735 and 3.787 Å) induce a two-fold interpenetration and thus effectively stabilize the framework of SNNU-35 (d,e). Charge-balanced [(CH3)­NH3]2+ cations are entrapped into the pores to further support this cage-based anionic framework.

However, such a Mg-MOF with large metal-organic cages will not be very stable due to the unsteady mono- or dinuclear Mg clusters. So two types of strong π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions (c, the center to center distances are of 3.735 and 3.787 Å) induce a two-fold interpenetration and thus effectively stabilize the framework of SNNU-35 (d,e). Charge-balanced [(CH3)NH3]2+ cations are entrapped into the pores to further support this cage-based anionic framework.

elements.content: Finally, from the perspective of topology, SNNU-35 exhibits a (3,4)-connected net with Mg3 and dinuclear cluster as 4-connected nodes and four unique BTB ligands as 3-connected nodes, respectively. The whole framework of SNNU-35 adopts a 3,3,3,3,4,4-c topological net (Figure S3) with the short Schläfli symbol of {6·82}3{62·8}3{83}2{6·85}3{62·84}3, which is different from the typical cubic ctn net or bor net found in cubic-C3N4. Furthermore, the structure of SNNU-35 can also be simplified to be an 8,8-connected 2-nodal net with a Schläfli symbol of {35·413·510}­{36·412·510} by assuming [Mg2] binuclear cluster and Mg3 monomer as two nodes. It is noted that an In-BTB framework constructed from two unique [In­(COO)4] monomers has the similar topological net as SNNU-35. Moreover, MIL-123 reported by Férey et al. is another Mg-BTB MOF crystallizing in a high-symmetrical space group (R-3), which is built up from two types of large superoctahedral cages, independently connected to each other to generate two-fold interpenetrated ReO3 nets. Similar to acetate anions in SNNU-35, the coordinated 1,4-dioxane molecules in MIL-123 help to reduce the coordination of amide solvent.

elements.content: When ditopic FDA ligands are utilized instead of tritopic BTB, a new rod-packing Mg-MOF, SNNU-36, is produced. SNNU-36 crystallizes in the tetragonal I4/mmm space group. As shown in a, the asymmetry unit contains two unique Mg­(II) ions, 1/2 FDA and 1/4 Ac anions. The occupancy of each Mg is 0.25. Mg1 is six-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from four FDA and one Ac anion ligands. Mg2 atom connects to six O atoms from four FDA and two Ac anions. The Mg–O distances range from 2.035(2) Å to 2.195(3) Å. Each FDA ligand adopts a μ4-kO;kO;kO;kO bridging mode to connect four Mg atoms (b). The Ac anion links Mg1 and Mg2 by the μ3-kO;kO,O;kO mode to give a one-dimensional (1D) [Mg2(Ac)] chain along the c-axis direction (c).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure of SNNU-36

When ditopic FDA ligands are utilized instead of tritopic BTB, a new rod-packing Mg-MOF, SNNU-36, is produced. SNNU-36 crystallizes in the tetragonal I4/mmm space group. As shown in a, the asymmetry unit contains two unique Mg(II) ions, 1/2 FDA and 1/4 Ac anions. The occupancy of each Mg is 0.25. Mg1 is six-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from four FDA and one Ac anion ligands. Mg2 atom connects to six O atoms from four FDA and two Ac anions. The Mg-O distances range from 2.035(2) Å to 2.195(3) Å. Each FDA ligand adopts a μ4-kO;kO;kO;kO bridging mode to connect four Mg atoms (b). The Ac anion links Mg1 and Mg2 by the μ3-kO;kO,O;kO mode to give a one-dimensional (1D) [Mg2(Ac)] chain along the c-axis direction (c).

elements.content: Crystal structures of SNNU-36: The basic coordination environments (a), the depiction of coordination mode of FDA ligand (b), 1D basic chain (c) and 3D framework viewed along the c-axis direction (d).
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structures of SNNU-36: The basic coordination environments (a), the depiction of coordination mode of FDA ligand (b), 1D basic chain (c) and 3D framework viewed along the c-axis direction (d).

elements.content: FDA ligands symmetrically surround each 1D chain and connect four near same Mg–Ac chains to extend into a 3D architecture of SNNU-36 (d). The distance between adjacent chains are of 5 Å, which is basically the length of FDA. On the other hand, SNNU-36 can also be viewed as a pillar-layered structure, as given in Figure S4. Notably, two types of 1D channels along the c-axis direction are observed with the opening sizes of the windows of about 7 × 7 and 8 × 8 Å2, respectively. The [(CH3)2NH2]2+ cations locate in the channel to further balance the whole framework charge. Since the 1D Mg–Ac chains can be simplified to be a rod-like secondary building units, thus the 3D framework of SNNU-36 can be regarded as a very common and simple rod-packing net with Mg–Ac chain as 4-connected rods. It is noted that we have also reported another high-symmetrical Mg-FDA MOF (CPM-203), which crystallizes in the chiral R32 space group. In CPM-203, [Mg3(μ3-OH)­(COO)6] clusters are connected by FDA ligands to form a 3D framework with pcu topology. As indicated above, the HFP additive is a key factor for the successful formation of CPM-203.

elements.content: Since the impurity may largely affect emission features of fluorescent metal–organic framework, the phase purity of SNNU-35-36 was investigated through powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) at room temperature. The good agreements between the experimental and simulated patterns clearly indicate the good phase homogeneity and purity of bulk samples of SNNU-35-36. Moreover, these Mg-MOFs can keep their frameworks after treated with common organic solvents for 24 h (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction and Thermogravimetric Analysis

Since the impurity may largely affect emission features of fluorescent metal-organic framework, the phase purity of SNNU-35-36 was investigated through powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) at room temperature. The good agreements between the experimental and simulated patterns clearly indicate the good phase homogeneity and purity of bulk samples of SNNU-35-36. Moreover, these Mg-MOFs can keep their frameworks after treated with common organic solvents for 24 h (Figure S5).

elements.content: Two MOFs were further studied by means of thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under air atmosphere. The TGA curves of SNNU-35-36 are provided in Figure S6. SNNU-35 showed two clear steps of weight loss in the range 30–250 °C and 450–660 °C, which should be assigned to the loss of coordinated water molecules and [(CH3)­NH3]2+ cations and BTB ligands and Ac anions, respectively. The final residual of 8.1% is close to the calculated value of 9.8% based on MgO. SNNU-36 had a total weight loss of 27.6% (cal 26.6%) from 25 to 300 °C, which is assigned to the loss of [(CH3)2NH2]2+ cations and Ac– anions. A total weight loss of 58.5% up to 570 °C is assigned to the complete decomposition of FDA ligand, and the final 15.9% residual (cal 16.5%) is ascribed to MgO.

elements.content: As described above, two ternary Mg-MOFs both are of porous frameworks. The void volumes calculated by the PLATON program are of 66.0% (45887.2 out of 69518.1 Å3 unit cell volumes) and 50.5% (2928.3 out of 5803.4 Å3 unit cell volumes) for SNNU-35 and SNNU-36, respectively. This encourages us to further evaluate their gas adsorption properties. The crystalline samples were subjected to solvent exchange by soaking in fresh dichloromethane for 5 days to activate SNNU-35 and -36 MOFs. The solvent-exchanged samples were dried and loaded into the sample tube of the sorption instrument to degas through heating. The N2 adsorption at 77 K showed that two MOFs both have negligible uptake amounts, which maybe due to the small pore sizes of SNNU-35-36 and the block of charge-balanced cations. Similar results have also been observed for iso-structural In-BTB MOF and other Mg-MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Uptake Performance

As described above, two ternary Mg-MOFs both are of porous frameworks. The void volumes calculated by the PLATON program are of 66.0% (45887.2 out of 69518.1 Å3 unit cell volumes) and 50.5% (2928.3 out of 5803.4 Å3 unit cell volumes) for SNNU-35 and SNNU-36, respectively. This encourages us to further evaluate their gas adsorption properties. The crystalline samples were subjected to solvent exchange by soaking in fresh dichloromethane for 5 days to activate SNNU-35 and -36 MOFs. The solvent-exchanged samples were dried and loaded into the sample tube of the sorption instrument to degas through heating. The N2 adsorption at 77 K showed that two MOFs both have negligible uptake amounts, which maybe due to the small pore sizes of SNNU-35-36 and the block of charge-balanced cations. Similar results have also been observed for iso-structural In-BTB MOF and other Mg-MOFs.

elements.content: The porosity of SNNU-35-36 MOFs is further supported by the adsorption experiments on smaller H2 and CO2 gas molecules. The adsorption amounts of H2 are 27.8 and 71.7 cm3·g–1 for SNNU-35 and -36 at 77 K and 1 atm, respectively. The CO2 sorption isotherms for SNNU-35 and -36 have been measured at 273 and 298 K. The gas sorption isotherms show the CO2 uptakes of 15.9 and 9.0 cm3·g–1 for SNNU-35, and 16.3 and 9.7 cm3·g–1 for SNNU-36, at 1 atm, 273 and 298 K (). Just as we pointed out above, the charge-balanced cations block the pores, and thus the H2 and CO2 uptakes of SNNU-35-36 are not remarkable compared to some famous gas uptake MOFs. Furthermore, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of CO2 was determined by fitting the adsorption data collected at 273 and 298 K to the virial model. At zero loading, indicative of the interaction of CO2 with the MOF framework, Q st 0 was determined to be 27.7 and 30.8 kJ/mol for SNNU-35 and SNNU-36, respectively (d and S7–S8). The Q st remained relatively constant and reached 22.1 and 24.2 kJ/mol at the maximum loading. These Q st values are comparable to our formerly reported anionic porous Zn-1,2,4-triazolate-carboxylate framework with amino-decorated polyhedral cages and higher than some other anionic frameworks, such as 25.38 kJ/mol in [(CH3)2NH2]3[(Cu4Cl)3(btc)8]·9DMA.

elements.content: Since two aromatic polycarboxylate ligands both have emission features from the perspective of chromophores, the photoluminescence property of H3BTB, H2FDA, and SNNU-35-36 MOFs in the solid state was investigated at room temperature. As shown in , the free H3BTB and H2FDA ligands exhibit the emission maxima at 367 and 376 nm, respectively. SNNU-35 shows a strong emission centered at 370 nm. Due to that the emission band of H3BTB is close to that of SNNU-35, there is no inner-filter effect of fluorescence between SNNU-35 and BTB. So, the fluorescence emission of SNNU-35 should be attributed to the immobilized H3BTB ligand in a rigid framework. The maximum emission peaks are at 443 for SNNU-36 under the excitation at 375 nm. Compared to the emission spectra of H2FDA ligand, SNNU-36 exhibits a certain level of red shifts, suggesting that the luminescence emission of SNNU-36 may be affected by the metal nodes and FDA ligand together.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Photoluminescence

Since two aromatic polycarboxylate ligands both have emission features from the perspective of chromophores, the photoluminescence property of H3BTB, H2FDA, and SNNU-35-36 MOFs in the solid state was investigated at room temperature. As shown in , the free H3BTB and H2FDA ligands exhibit the emission maxima at 367 and 376 nm, respectively. SNNU-35 shows a strong emission centered at 370 nm. Due to that the emission band of H3BTB is close to that of SNNU-35, there is no inner-filter effect of fluorescence between SNNU-35 and BTB. So, the fluorescence emission of SNNU-35 should be attributed to the immobilized H3BTB ligand in a rigid framework. The maximum emission peaks are at 443 for SNNU-36 under the excitation at 375 nm. Compared to the emission spectra of H2FDA ligand, SNNU-36 exhibits a certain level of red shifts, suggesting that the luminescence emission of SNNU-36 may be affected by the metal nodes and FDA ligand together.

elements.content: Solid-state fluorescent spectra of SNNU-35 and BTB (a) and SNNU-36 and FDA (b) at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 4  Solid-state fluorescent spectra of SNNU-35 and BTB (a) and SNNU-36 and FDA (b) at room temperature.

elements.content: The aggregation of BTB/FDA ligands with fluorophore units endows strong fluorescence features in the frameworks of SNNU-35-36. Moreover, the high porosity of these two MOFs provides the passage for the diffusion of the target molecules. Enhancing the interaction between MOF fluorescent material and target molecules leads to weakened or enhanced original fluorescence intensity, and the change of light signal can be detected in fluorescence spectrometer. These results mean that SNNU-35-36 may be a good fluorescence sensing material candidate.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Sensing Performance

The aggregation of BTB/FDA ligands with fluorophore units endows strong fluorescence features in the frameworks of SNNU-35-36. Moreover, the high porosity of these two MOFs provides the passage for the diffusion of the target molecules. Enhancing the interaction between MOF fluorescent material and target molecules leads to weakened or enhanced original fluorescence intensity, and the change of light signal can be detected in fluorescence spectrometer. These results mean that SNNU-35-36 may be a good fluorescence sensing material candidate.

elements.content: It is well-known that flammable, toxic nitroaromatics are electron deficiently conjugated and can lead to fluorescence quenching for a porous and electron-rich luminescent MOF due to the electron or energy transfer. Thus, three basic nitrocompounds with different sizes, nitrobenzene (NB), o-nitrotoluene (2-NT), and nitromethane (NM) have been selected in this work as models to investigate the fluorescent sensing performance of SNNU-35-36 MOFs.
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that flammable, toxic nitroaromatics are electron deficiently conjugated and can lead to fluorescence quenching for a porous and electron-rich luminescent MOF due to the electron or energy transfer. Thus, three basic nitrocompounds with different sizes, nitrobenzene (NB), o-nitrotoluene (2-NT), and nitromethane (NM) have been selected in this work as models to investigate the fluorescent sensing performance of SNNU-35-36 MOFs.

elements.content: As shown in , with the continuous addition of NB and 2-NT, the fluorescent intensity of SNNU-35 decreases rapidly. The additions of 200 ppm of NB and 400 ppm 2-NT lead to 5.5% and 19.2% fluorescence quenching. These values are 22.0 and 11.6% for SNNU-36. When the additions of NB reach 5000 ppm, the fluorescence quenching of SNNU-35 and -36 is of 96.3% and 89.5%. Also, approximately 85.0% and 83.7% fluorescence quenching occurred through the addition of 8000 ppm of 2-NT for SNNU-35 and -36, respectively. These values show that at lower concentrations of nitroaromatics, SNNU-35 is more sensitive to 2-NT, but SNNU-36 is more sensitive to NB. This may be caused by the larger steric hindrance of 2-NT, which cannot rapidly diffuse in to the smaller channels of SNNU-36. Furthermore, the fluorescent sensing performance for nitromethane (NM) was also done to evaluate the selectivity of SNNU-35-36 sensors. As shown in , two Mg-MOFs both show negligible fluorescence quenching performance for NM even when the concentration reaches 8000 ppm. This result clearly shows that SNNU-35-36 MOF sensors have good selectivity between aromatic and non-aromatic compounds. In our opinion, this is caused by the fact that the strong fluorescence features in SNNU-35-36 frameworks are mainly originated from the aromatic BTB/FDA fluorophore units. Thus, although smaller non-aromatic NM molecules can diffuse into the MOF pores easily, they cannot effectively weaken the original fluorescence intensity through electron or energy transfer.

elements.content: Since the fluorescence intensity was intimately dependent on the concentration of NB and 2-NT, the fluorescent sensing performance of SNNU-35-36 can be analyzed using the Stern–Volmer equation: I/I 0 = 1 + K sv C. I 0 is the fluorescence intensities in pure solvent and C is the concentration of NB or 2-NT. As given in , the SV plots of NB and 2-NT are nearly linear with the R 2 values of 0.9873 and 0.9891 for SNNU-35 and 0.9793 and 0.9812 for SNNU-36. The calculated detection limits of SNNU-35 for NB and 2-NT are 7.42 and 36.92 ppm, respectively. These values are 12.63 and 81.12 ppm for SNNU-36. The good linearity indicates that Mg-MOF sensors can be used to quantatively detect nitroaromatics. Correspondingly, the K sv values of NB and 2-NT are 3.9 × 105 M–1 and 6.2 × 105 M–1 for SNNU-35 and 1.2 × 105 M–1 and 3.7 × 105 M–1 for SNNU-36, respectively. These large K sv values show that two Mg-MOFs both display strong quenching effects on the NB and 2-NT and SNNU-35 is slightly better than SNNU-36. Overall, fluorescent Mg-MOFs have nanocages or channels, which can adsorb NB or 2-NT molecules to change the charge distribution on MOF material surfaces and thus lead to effective fluorescence quenching.

These large K  sv  values show that two Mg-MOFs both display strong quenching effects on the NB and 2-NT and SNNU-35 is slightly better than SNNU-36. Overall, fluorescent Mg-MOFs have nanocages or channels, which can adsorb NB or 2-NT molecules to change the charge distribution on MOF material surfaces and thus lead to effective fluorescence quenching.

elements.content: In summary, with acetate as modulator, two novel high-symmetrical luminescent Mg-MOFs were successfully designed herein by utilizing aromatic polycarboxylate ligands with chromophore. Interpenetration of nanocages and rod-packing fashion makes two Mg-MOFs of 3D anionic architectures with large cages or 1D channels. Due to the electron-rich surface and the porous passage, two Mg-MOFs can act as fluorescent sensors exhibiting sensitive, fast, quantative, and selective detection for nitroaromatics. Future study will be focused on the exploration of new high-symmetrical Mg-MOF sensors and understanding the relationship between sensing performance and MOF structure.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, with acetate as modulator, two novel high-symmetrical luminescent Mg-MOFs were successfully designed herein by utilizing aromatic polycarboxylate ligands with chromophore. Interpenetration of nanocages and rod-packing fashion makes two Mg-MOFs of 3D anionic architectures with large cages or 1D channels. Due to the electron-rich surface and the porous passage, two Mg-MOFs can act as fluorescent sensors exhibiting sensitive, fast, quantative, and selective detection for nitroaromatics. Future study will be focused on the exploration of new high-symmetrical Mg-MOF sensors and understanding the relationship between sensing performance and MOF structure.

cln_elements.content: Two MOFs were further studied by means of thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under air atmosphere. The TGA curves of SNNU-35-36 are provided in Figure S6. SNNU-35 showed two clear steps of weight loss in the range 30–250 °C and 450–660 °C, which should be assigned to the loss of coordinated water molecules and [(CH3)­NH3]2+ cations and BTB ligands and Ac anions, respectively. The final residual of 8.1% is close to the calculated value of 9.8% based on MgO. SNNU-36 had a total weight loss of 27.6% (cal 26.6%) from 25 to 300 °C, which is assigned to the loss of [(CH3)2NH2]2+ cations and Ac– anions. A total weight loss of 58.5% up to 570 °C is assigned to the complete decomposition of FDA ligand, and the final 15.9% residual (cal 16.5%) is ascribed to MgO.

Design of High-Symmetrical Magnesium-Organic Frameworks
